borough: London Borough of Barking and Dagenham
decision_conditions: <p>The proposed development, by reason of its mass, design and sitting, would generate a harmful loss of amenity to both neighbouring properties.&nbsp; The proposal is therefore contrary to the following:</p><p>-&nbsp;Paragraph 130 of the National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021)</p><p>- Policy Policy D6 of the London Plan;</p><p>- Policy CP3 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010)</p><p>-&nbsp; Policy BP8 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011);</p><p>- Policy DMD1, DMD6 of the&nbsp;The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)</p><p><br></p>

<p>The proposed extensions are considered incongruous and unsympathetic additions which would add significant mass and bulking to the existing property and would harm the character of the site in relation to the wider context. As such, the proposal is considered contrary to the following:</p><p>- Section 12, Paragraphs 130 and 134 of the&nbsp;National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021);</p><p>- Policy D4 of the&nbsp;London Plan (March 2021);</p><p>- Policy CP3 of the Local Development Framework (LDF) Core Strategy (July 2010);</p><p>- Policy BP11 of the&nbsp;Local Development Framework (LDF) Borough Wide Development Plan Document (DPD) (March 2011);</p><p>- Policy SP2 and DMD1, DMD6 of the&nbsp;The London Borough of Barking and Dagenham’s Draft Local Plan: (Regulation 19 Submission Version, December 2021)<br></p>

<p><span style="font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, sans-serif;">The proposed development fails to provide exemplary quality of internal and external accommodation for its future residents to combat the potential negative impact arising from splitting a single house into two flats.&nbsp; As such, the development is considered unacceptable and contrary to:-</span><o:p></o:p></p><p>- Chapter 6 of the&nbsp;National Planning Policy Framework (NPPF) (DLUHC, 2021);</p><p><span style="font-size: 11pt;">- Policy D6 of the London Plan (March 2021);</span></p><p><span style="font-size: 11pt;">-</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Policy BP5 of the Borough Wide Development Policy DPD (March 2011);</span></p><p><span style="font-size: 11pt;">-</span><span style="font-size: 11pt;">Policy DMD 1 of the draft Local Plan&nbsp;</span><span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;">(Regulation 19 Consultation version, Autumn 2021)</span></p><p><span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;">-&nbsp;</span><font face="Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif"><span style="font-size: 14.6667px;">DCLG Technical Housing Standards (nationally described space standard) (DCLG, March 2015) (as amended)</span></font></p>

<p><span style="text-align: justify; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, sans-serif;">The proposed development is for conversion of an existing family house that has the flexibility to be extended to meet changing and larger family needs into three flats. This&nbsp;</span><span style="text-align: justify; font-size: 11pt; font-family: Arial, sans-serif;">type of housing is in high demand in the borough and it is important that they are protected rather than split into smaller houses or flats. Having regard to the presumption in favour of sustainable development, on balance it is considered that the negatives arising from the proposal outweigh the positives. For the reasons outlines above, the development is considered unacceptable and contrary to:-</span><br></p><div><p style="text-align: justify;"><o:p></o:p></p></div><p>-Paragraph 11(d) of the National Planning Policy Framework (DLUHC, 2021);</p><p>- Policy H10 of the London Plan (March 2021)</p><p>- Policy CC1 of the Core Strategy DPD (July 2010)</p><p>- Policy BC4 of the Borough Wide Development Policies DPD (March 2011)</p><p>- Policies SPDG 1 and SP3 of the Draft Local Plan (Regulation 19 consultation version, Autumn 2021)</p><p>- London Borough of Barking and Dagenham Housing Delivery Test Action Plan 2020</p><p>-&nbsp;<span style="font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 11pt;">Strategic Housing Marking Assessment (SHMA) published in February 2020</span></p>
description: Construction of a double storey rear extension, hip to gable roof extension, rear dormer roof extension, installation of two rooflights in the front roofslope, removal of existing chimney stack, and conversion of existing 4-bedroom dwellinghouse to 3x self-contained flats (1x 3-bedrooms and 2x 2-bedrooms)
